{{Infobox football club | clubname = Mathare Youth | image = [[Image:Mathare Youth.png|100px|Logo]] | fullname = Mathare Youth Football Club | nickname = | founded = | dissolved = {{End date|2012|8|31|df=y}} | ground = [[Ruaraka Sports Ground]]
[[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]] | capacity = 4,000 | chairman = Peter Karanja | manager = David Ouma Kenyafootball, October 17, 2008: [http://kenyafootball.com/index.php?doc=story&id=3097&categ=1&PHPSESSID=edf4ee4a99071ac79532bd982 Ouma replaces ‘Kingi’ at Mathare Youth] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120225222114/http://kenyafootball.com/index.php?doc=story&id=3097&categ=1&PHPSESSID=edf4ee4a99071ac79532bd982 |date=2012-02-25 }} | league = | season = | position = | pattern_la1 = | pattern_b1 = | pattern_ra1 = | leftarm1 = ffff00 | body1 = ffff00 | rightarm1 = ffff00 | shorts1 = ffff00 | socks1 = ffff00 }} '''Mathare Youth Football Club''' was a [[association football|football]] club based in [[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]].[http://www.rsssf.com/tablesk/kenya07.html RSSSF] They played in the [[Kenyan Premier League]], but were relegated in 2008. They last competed in the [[FKF Division One]]. The team was owned by the [[Mathare Youth Sports Association]].[http://www.kpl.co.ke/content.asp?id=15242 KPL website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081218181603/http://www.kpl.co.ke/content.asp?id=15242 |date=2008-12-18 }} The team was a feeder team for [[Mathare United F.C.|Mathare United]], until Mathare Youth were promoted to the Premier League to rival them. On 31 August 2012, the team disbanded and therefore pulled out of the [[2012 FKF Division One]], after which the [[Football Kenya Federation]] decided to nullify all of their second round results.{{cite web|title=FKF makes decision after Mathare Youth pullout|url=http://www.futaa.com/football/article/fkf-makes-decision-after-mathare-youth-pullout|author=Patrick Korir|publisher=Futaa.com|date=21 September 2012 |accessdate=23 September 2012}} This meant that all teams that had played against them had their points revoked or given back, depending on the results of the matches,{{cite web|title=Celtic disappointed by FKF's decision |url=http://www.futaa.com/football/article/celtic-disappointed-by-fkfs-decision |author=Brian Moseti |publisher=Futaa.com |date=22 September 2012 |accessdate=23 September 2012}} and all upcoming fixtures involving them were cancelled. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{FKF Division One}} {{Kenyan Premier League plain}} [[Category:FKF Division One clubs]] [[Category:Football clubs in Kenya]] [[Category:Sport in Nairobi]] [[Category:Association football clubs disestablished in 2012]] {{Kenya-footyclub-stub}}

[[File:The Great north side, or, Borough of the Bronx, New York (1897) (14578537047).jpg|thumb|1897]] '''Morris Park Racecourse''' was an American [[Thoroughbred horse race|thoroughbred horse racing]] facility from 1889 until 1904. It was located in a part of [[Westchester County, New York]] that was annexed into [[the Bronx]] in 1895 and later became known as [[Morris Park, Bronx|Morris Park]]. The racecourse was the site of the [[Belmont Stakes]] from 1890 through 1904 as well as the [[Preakness Stakes]] in 1890.
==History== Morris Park Racecourse was conceived and built by majority shareholder [[John Albert Morris]] as a result of the planned closure of the nearby [[Jerome Park Racetrack]], where racing ended in 1894 to make way for the [[Jerome Park Reservoir]]. Principal owner John Morris had extensive business interests in [[Louisiana]] and the prominent New York businessman and horseracing enthusiast [[Leonard W. Jerome]] served as the racecourse's president. [[African-American]] [[National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame|Racing Hall of Fame]] jockey [[Isaac Burns Murphy|Isaac Murphy]] rode on opening day at the new facility—August 20, 1889—and Morris Park was described as "the finest race track in the world."<ref>[[#DiBrino|DiBrino 1977]], p.5.</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Geraldine's New Record; Made Yesterday at the New Race Track. A Most Successful Opening Day at the Finest Race Track in the World |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=August 21, 1889 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1889/08/21/archives/geraldines-new-record-made-yesterday-at-the-new-race-track-a-most.html |accessdate=2009-08-23}}</ref> Accessible by horse and buggy, the [[New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad]] added a short spur from its main line near the [[Van Nest, Bronx|Van Nest]] station that brought racing fans directly to the new race track from the greater [[New York City]] area.<ref name="nyt1889-05-12">{{cite news |title=New West Chester Track; The Home of the New-York Jockey Club. Progress of the Work at the Track, Which Will Be the Finest Race Course in the World |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=May 12, 1889 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1889/05/12/archives/new-west-chester-track-the-home-of-the-newyork-jockey-club-progress.html |accessdate=2009-08-23}}</ref>
The track held the [[USA Cross Country Championships]] from 1890 to 1892 and 1897 to 1898.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.therealxc.com|title=The Accurate Database of U.S. National Champions|publisher=therealxc.com|accessdate=2018-09-14}}</ref>
On June 10, 1890, Morris Park Racecourse hosted both the Preakness and Belmont Stakes.<ref>{{cite news |title=Burlington a Racehorse; He Wins the Twenty-Third Belmont in Good Style |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1890/06/11/archives/burlington-a-racehorse-he-wins-the-twentythird-belmont-in-good.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 11, 1890 |accessdate=2009-10-13}}</ref> While the Preakness Stakes was canceled for three years then restarted in 1894 at [[Gravesend Race Track]] on [[Coney Island]], the Belmont Stakes was held at Morris Park until it moved to [[Belmont Park]] on [[Long Island]] in 1905. During this same period of 1890 through 1904, the [[Champagne Stakes (United States)|Champagne Stakes]] and the [[Ladies Handicap]] were also raced here. The [[Metropolitan Handicap]] was inaugurated here in 1891 as was the [[Matron Stakes (United States)|Matron Stakes]] the following year.
A few days before he died in May 1895, John Morris leased the racecourse, with an option to purchase, to the Westchester Racing Association. Although the 1½ mile racecourse was modified to a one-mile circuit to allow for better spectator viewing, a lack of patronage by [[upper class|high society]] members meant the clubhouse was usually empty. By 1902, the decline in attendance resulted in the decision to close Morris Park Racecourse.<ref>{{cite news |title=New Race Track Planned; Morris Park to be Abandoned for a Course on Long Island |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 26, 1902 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1902/11/26/archives/new-race-track-planned-morris-park-to-be-abandoned-for-a-course-on.html |accessdate=2009-08-23}}</ref> The final day of races was held on October 15, 1904, and racing shifted to the new Belmont Park the following year.<ref>{{cite news |title=Record Was Broken at Morris Park's Last Day; Artful Set a New World's Mark for Six Furlongs Down the Hill |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 16, 1904 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1904/10/16/archives/record-was-broken-at-morris-parks-last-day-artful-set-a-new-worlds.html |accessdate=2009-08-23}}</ref>
After its closure, the Morris Park Racecourse was used for [[automobile racing]] but a few years later the Morris heirs sold the property to real estate developers. The new owners ran into financial problems which resulted in the track being taken over by the City of New York in 1907. The city then leased it for two years to the Aeronautic Society of New York who hosted the first public [[air show]] on the grounds. In June 1909, [[Glenn H. Curtiss]] put on a flying exhibition at Morris Park.<ref>{{cite news |title=Curtiss Flies Here; In the Air a Minute at Morris Park Race Course |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 17, 1909 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1909/06/17/archives/curtiss-flies-here-in-the-air-a-minute-at-morris-park-race-course.html |accessdate=2009-08-23}}</ref>
On April 10, 1910 a fire ravaged much of the stables and nearby facilities.<ref>{{cite news |title=Flames Sweep Old Morris Park Track; Westchester Village Endangered by Fire Which Destroys Famous Stables |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=April 11, 1910 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1910/04/11/archives/flames-sweep-old-morris-park-track-westchester-village-endangered.html |accessdate=2009-08-23}}</ref> Three years later the property was auctioned off to developers who would subdivide the land into building lots. As late as 1921 the clubhouse was still intact when it was sold as part of a 14-lot package to a company who converted it for use as a factory to manufacture [[ornamental iron]].<ref>{{cite news |title=The Bronx Market; Part of Old Morris Park Race Track for Iron Factory |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 21, 1921 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1921/07/21/archives/the-bronx-market-part-of-old-morris-park-race-track-for-iron.html |accessdate=2009-08-23}}</ref>
==Physical attributes== Morris Park Racecourse was situated in the area bounded on the south by Sackett Avenue and by what is today the [[Amtrak]] [[Northeast Corridor]] railroad right-of-way, on the east by Williamsbridge Road, on the west by what is now Bronxdale Road, and on the north by [[Pelham Parkway (road)|Pelham Parkway]]. The grandstand stood at the intersection of Bogart and Fowler Avenues and the clubhouse was near the intersection of Fowler and Van Nest Avenues.<ref>[[#DiBrino|DiBrino 1977]], p.3.</ref><ref>{{cite map |publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]] |title=New York-New Jersey Harlem Quadrangle |url=http://docs.unh.edu/nhtopos/Harlem.htm|year=1900|scale=1:62,500 |series=15 Minute Series (Topographic) |section=SE |accessdate=2009-08-23}}</ref>
The racetrack covered {{convert|360|acre|km²}} and had a grandstand {{convert|650|ft|m}} long that could accommodate up to 15,000 attendees. The main track had circumference of {{convert|1+1/2|mi|km|abbr=on}}, with a stretch that was {{convert|2250|ft|m}} long and widened from {{convert|80|ft|m}} at the top of the homestretch to {{convert|240|ft|m}} at the finish line. The north end of the track was located on a hill so horses had to run uphill on the backstretch and downhill on the homestretch. A [[Chute (racecourse)|chute]] on the main track permitted races of {{convert|1+1/8|mi|km|abbr=on}} to be run with one turn. Another track called the Eclipse course ran diagonally across the main track on a straightaway of {{convert|3/4|mi|km|abbr=on}}, joining the main track at its finish line. It was named after Eclipse, a horse owned by Francis Morris. A six furlongs race on the Eclipse course was nicknamed the "Toboggan Slide" and continues to be run today at [[Aqueduct Racetrack]] as the [[Toboggan Handicap]]. The stables at Morris Park Racecourse held a total of 1,000 stalls, more than any two of the other American racetracks combined.<ref name="nyt1889-05-12"/><ref>[[#DiBrino|DiBrino 1977]], p.4.</ref><ref>{{cite book |editor-last=Worman |editor-first=James H. |title=Outing |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q6vQAAAAMAAJ |accessdate=2009-08-23 |volume=20 |year=1892 |publisher=The Outing Company, Ltd. |location=New York |pages=131–132}}</ref>
== Other defunct New York race tracks == * [[Brighton Beach Race Course]] * [[Gravesend Race Track]] * [[Jamaica Racetrack]] * [[Jerome Park Racetrack]] * [[Roosevelt Raceway (harness racing)|Roosevelt Raceway]] * [[Sheepshead Bay Race Track]] * [[Union Course]]
==See also== * [[1905 Morris Park 5]]
==References== ;Notes {{Reflist|2}}
;Bibliography {{Refbegin}} *{{cite book |last=DiBrino |first=Nicholas |title=The History of the Morris Park Racecourse and the Morris Family |year=1977 |publisher=Bronx County Historical Society |location=Bronx |isbn=978-0-941980-27-2|ref=DiBrino}} {{Refend}}
==External links== * [http://www.bronxnyc.com East Bronx History Forum]

{{Motorsport venue |Name = Moscow Raceway |Nicknames = |Time = [[Moscow Time|MSK+00]] ([[Universal Time Coordinate|UTC+04]]) |Location = {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Volokolamsk]], [[Moscow Oblast]], [[Russia]] |Coordinates = {{coord|55|59|45.8|N|36|16|6.1|E|type:landmark}} |Image = [[File:Moscow Raceway Grand-prix Circuit.svg|250px]] |Image_caption = |Capacity = 30,000[http://www.concert.ru/Pictures/000060138.jpg Map and technical characteristics] |FIAGrade = [[Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile|FIA]] 1
[[Fédération Internationale de Motocyclisme|FIM]] B |Owner = |Operator = |Broke_ground = {{Start date|2008|09}} |Opened = {{Start date|2012|07|13}} |Closed = |Construction_cost= 4.5 billion [[Russian ruble|rub.]]
~[[United States Dollar|$]]150 million |Architect = [[Hermann Tilke]] |Former_names = |Events = [[Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters|DTM]]

[[FIA GT3 European Championship]]
[[World Touring Car Championship|FIA WTCC]]
[[Russian Touring Car Championship|RTCC]]
[[World Series by Renault]]
[[Superbike World Championship|World Superbike]] |Layout1 = Grand Prix 1 |Surface = Asphalt |Length_km = 3.955 |Length_mi = 2.46 |Turns = 15 |Banking = |Record_time = 1:24.831 |Record_driver = [[Arthur Pic]] |Record_team = [[DAMS]] |Record_year = [[2012 Formula Renault 3.5 Series season|2012]] |Record_class = [[World Series by Renault|Formula Renault 3.5 Series]] |Layout2 = Grand Prix 9 |Surface2 = Asphalt |Length_km2 = 3.931 |Length_mi2 = 2.44 |Turns2 = 14 |Banking2 = |Record_time2 = 1:21.686 |Record_driver2 = [[Stoffel Vandoorne]] |Record_team2 = [[Fortec Motorsport]] |Record_year2 = [[2013 Formula Renault 3.5 Series season|2013]] |Record_class2 = [[World Series by Renault|Formula Renault 3.5 Series]] |Layout3 = Sprint 4 |Surface3 = Asphalt |Length_km3 = 2.555 |Length_mi3 = 1.588 |Turns3 = 10 |Record_time3 = 0:58.999 |Record_driver3 = [[Adrien Tambay]] |Record_team3 = [[Abt Sportsline|Audi Sport Team Abt]] |Record_year3 = [[2013 Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters season|2013]] |Record_class3 = [[Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters]] }} '''Moscow Raceway''' is an [[Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile|FIA]]-approved [[Motorsport#Motor racing|motor racing]] venue, which is situated in the [[Volokolamsk|Volokolamsky District]] of [[Moscow Oblast]], near the villages of Sheludkovo and Fedyukovo, {{convert|97|km}} from [[Moscow]], [[Russia]]. It opened on 13 July 2012 for its first event as the fifth round of the [[World Series by Renault]] becoming the first major international motor-sport [[race track]] event in [[Russia]]. ==History== In September 2008, it was revealed that work was to begin on a Formula One circuit to be located at the village of Fedyukovo, Volokolamsky District. Official presentation of the project and laying of the first stone was held at the site on 1 October 2008, attended by architect [[Hermann Tilke]] and [[Formula One]] driver [[David Coulthard]]. Hans Geist, who at that time was the managing director of the project, stated that the track could pass an FIA inspection by June 2010, and that even without Formula 1 the project would be profitable staging either [[Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters|DTM]] or [[Grand Prix motorcycle racing|MotoGP]]. The cost of the project overall was 4.5 billion [[Russian ruble|rub]] when it opened on 13 July 2012. ===Design=== Moscow Raceway was designed to be categorized FIA 1T and FIM A, which would allow motorsport competition at any level, from national championships in auto and motorcycle racing, to Formula 1 and MotoGP.{{cite news |url=http://www.gpupdate.net/en/f1-news/199780/moscow-to-start-construction-work-this-week/ |title=Moscow to start construction work this week |publisher=GPUpdate |date=30 September 2008 |accessdate=31 January 2011}} The total designed track length is {{convert|4070|m|mi}}, with widths of between {{convert|12|m}} and {{convert|21|m}}. The start/finish line has a width of {{convert|15|m}} at an elevation of {{convert|22|m}}. The longest straight of {{convert|873|m}} is designed to allow Formula 1 cars to reach a speed of {{convert|311|km/h}}.[http://moscowraceway.ru/ Moscow Raceway] The circuit was finally classified as a FIM B grade course following inspections on 18 July 2012, one grade down from what was expected.{{cite web|title=FIM Inspection: Moscow Raceway gets homologation for Eni FIM Superbike World Championship|url=http://www.moscowraceway.com/eng/index.php?pid=2&record_id=66|work=www.moscowraceway.com|accessdate=2012-08-07|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130129235951/http://www.moscowraceway.com/eng/index.php?pid=2&record_id=66#|archive-date=2013-01-29|dead-url=yes|df=}} ===Construction=== Built under a Russian–[[Germany|German]] joint venture named "Autobahn", the general contractor for construction of buildings and race track to international level was Stroytech-5, a member of a group of companies Stroytech.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} Sub-contract partners included [[Siemens]]{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}}, while [[Sergei Krylov (racing driver)|Sergei Krylov]] was working as an adviser.{{cite web |url=http://rbth.ru/articles/2008/11/27/271108_formula.html |title=Fast tracking Formula One |date=2008-11-27 |accessdate=2018-07-28}} After initially signing a deal with [[Bernie Ecclestone]] in 2008, the project was dropped from the 2010 Formula 1 calendar in early 2009, and construction stopped. Construction resumed in June 2010, with the new contractor agreeing to complete the road section of the track by the end of 2011. By September 2011, all asphalt laying had been completed, and construction of the associated pit, support and medical buildings was being undertaken. ==Race history== [[File:Eurocup Formula Renault 2.0 Moscow Raceway 2012.JPG|thumb|right|[[Eurocup Formula Renault 2.0]] race at Moscow Raceway in 2012.]] The first events held at the circuit were part of the [[World Series by Renault]] on 13–15 July 2012, where it also became the second international motor-sport event in Russian history after the FIA European Truck Racing Championship event took place in the Smolenskring in July 2010.{{cite web|title=World Series by Renault a big hit in Russia|url=http://www.worldseriesbyrenault.fr/en/tv_news/news/Pages/WorldSeriesbyRenaultabighitinRussia.aspx|work=worldseriesbyrenault.fr|publisher=Renault Group|accessdate=2012-07-19|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120821093041/http://www.worldseriesbyrenault.fr/en/tv_news/news/Pages/WorldSeriesbyRenaultabighitinRussia.aspx#|archive-date=2012-08-21|dead-url=yes|df=}} The first race itself was the 5th round of the [[2012 Formula Renault 3.5 Series season|Formula Renault 3.5 series]], which was won by Dutchman [[Robin Frijns]].{{cite web|title=Flying Frijns first to win in Russia|url=http://www.worldseriesbyrenault.fr/en/tv_news/news/Pages/FlyingFrijnsfirsttowininRussia.aspx|work=worldseriesbyrenault.fr|publisher=Renault Group|accessdate=2012-07-14}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The first Russian to win a race there soon followed with [[Daniil Kvyat]] winning both races of the [[Eurocup Formula Renault 2.0|Eurocup Formula Renault 2.0 series]] round in a row.{{cite web|title=Home win for Russia’s Kvyat|url=http://www.worldseriesbyrenault.fr/en/tv_news/news/Pages/HomewinforRussiasKvyat.aspx|work=worldseriesbyrenault.fr|publisher=Renault Group|accessdate=2012-07-14|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120826221918/http://www.worldseriesbyrenault.fr/en/tv_news/news/Pages/HomewinforRussiasKvyat.aspx|archivedate=2012-08-26}}{{cite web|title=Kvyat does it again|url=http://www.worldseriesbyrenault.fr/en/tv_news/news/Pages/Kvyatdoesitagain.aspx|work=worldseriesbyrenault.fr|publisher=Renault Group|accessdate=2012-07-15|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120815070846/http://www.worldseriesbyrenault.fr/en/tv_news/news/Pages/Kvyatdoesitagain.aspx|archivedate=2012-08-15}} A total of 10 Russian drivers were at the event including former 3.5 series Champion [[Mikhail Aleshin]]; many taking over other drivers for just this event. On 21 July 2013, during the [[2013 Superbike World Championship season|World Superbike]] weekend, Italian rider [[Andrea Antonelli]] was killed in the [[2013 Supersport World Championship season|World Supersport]] race after being hit on the back straight by fellow rider [[Lorenzo Zanetti]]. Antonelli was airlifted to hospital where he died of massive head trauma, and the rest of the weekend's action was cancelled due to the torrential downpour that unquestionably contributed to the fatal crash. ==Configurations== ===Layouts=== File:Moscow Raceway Grand-prix Circuit.svg|"Grand Prix Circuit", used in 2012 File:Moscow Raceway FIM.svg|"Grand Prix Circuit", used for the [[Superbike World Championship]] and [[World Series by Renault]] (from 2013) File:Moscow Raceway Sprint Circuit Configuration.png|"Sprint Circuit", used for [[Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters|DTM]] File:Moscow Raceway Supersprint Circuit Configuration.png|"Supersprint Circuit" ==Facilities== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:95%" ! Track ! Distance ! Corners ! Grade |- | Grand Prix 1 |align=center| 3.955 km |align=center| 15 |align=center| [[Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile|FIA]] 1T |- | Grand Prix 9 |align=center| 3.931 km |align=center| 14 |align=center| [[Fédération Internationale de Motocyclisme|FIM]] B |- | Sprint |align=center| 2.661 km |align=center| 12 |align=center| N/A |- | Supersprint |align=center| 1.357 km |align=center| 10 |align=center| N/A |- | Full Circuit | 4.070 km |align=center| 21 |align=center| '''—''' |} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://moscowraceway.ru/en/ Moscow Raceway official site ] {{en icon}} {{coord|56.000278|N|36.268889|E|source:ruwiki_region:RU_scale:10000|format=dms|display=title}} {{Navboxes |list1 = {{World Series by Renault circuits}} {{SBK circuits}} {{FIA GT1 circuits}} {{DTM circuits}} {{WTCC circuits}} {{FIA F3 European Championship circuits}}}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Moscow Raceway}} [[Category:Motorsport venues in Russia]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Moscow Oblast]] [[Category:World Touring Car Championship circuits]] [[Category:Racing circuits designed by Hermann Tilke]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2008]] [[Category:2008 establishments in Russia]] [[Category:Sports venues in Moscow Oblast]]

revision.comment: - 4 categories; ±[[Category:Standards organizations]]→[[Category:Standards organizations in the United States]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
The '''National Operating Committee on Standards for Athletic Equipment''' (NOCSAE) is a [[non-profit organization]] operating in the [[United States]], whose mission is to reduce athletic injuries and death through standards and certification for [[athletic equipment]]. Schools and universities look to NOCSAE certification of equipment, particularly [[football helmet|helmets]], to protect players and reduce liability. NOCSAE data indicate a significant reduction in athlete fatalities and brain injuries when using NOCSAE-certified equipment. NOCSAE has been criticized for stifling innovation, holding a conflict of interest, and not furthering true player safety.
==Creation and early years== NOCSAE was organized in 1969 with the purpose of reducing death and injuries through the establishment of standards and certification for athletic equipment.<ref name=Wong /><ref name=Magee /> It does this through researching and testing equipment, developing new standards, and improving existing ones.<ref name=Wong />
NOCSAE's commissioning came in the wake of the death of 32 players in [[professional football (gridiron)|organized football]] in 1968 and subsequent concerns over safety of athletic equipment.<ref name=Magee /> Based on its limited funding, NOCSAE has narrowed its efforts from protective athletic equipment in all sports toward helmets' effectiveness in reducing injury, particularly in football, [[lacrosse]], and [[baseball]].<ref name=Magee /><ref name=Lipsey />
==NOCSAE standards, adoption, and effects== As a general matter, to be approved by NOCSAE, helmets must resist brain-injuring, concussive forces.<ref name=Magee /> Research from NOCSAE, in addition to targeting helmet safety standards, has also increased understanding of the mechanisms of head and neck injuries and the design and structure of helmets, headgear, and [[face mask (gridiron football)|face mask]]s.<ref name=Lipsey />
NOCSAE standards are adopted, if at all, on a voluntary basis. While a sport governing body may mandate that a piece of equipment be "NOCSAE approved", that is a rule or mandate of the governing body, not NOCSAE.<ref name=Hillman />
By 1973, NOCSAE had finalized and published a standard testing criteria for football helmets.<ref name=Magee /> The [[NCAA]] began advising its members to purchase helmets certified by NOCSAE beginning in 1975.<ref name=Nelson /> NOCSAE helmet standards were required in colleges in 1978 and in high schools in 1980.<ref name=Hillman />
Stickers indicating NOCSAE certification are placed onto helmets.<ref name=Amato /> Attorneys specializing in sports law advise schools and universities to purchase appropriate athletic equipment for the athletic activities offered that is of satisfactory quality, specifically football helmets that adhere to NOCSAE guidelines.<ref name=Wong /> School athletic staff are advised by experts to search for NOCSAE certification stickers, both as part of their athletic training education and day-to-day activities .<ref name=Wong /><ref name=Amato /> They are warned to do this, in particular, for liability reasons, as "serious legal reprecussions may occur if a helmet is issued to a student athletic " lacking an approval sticker.<ref name=Eaves />
NOCSAE reports that by 1985, the number of head injury fatalities had fallen significantly, with zero deaths in 1990, the first season with no deaths since reporting began in 1931.<ref name=Wong /> It also claims that the incidence of serious head injuries had fallen from 4.25 players per 100,000 in the late 1960s to 0.68 players per 100,000 in the late 1980s.<ref name=Wong />
==Board membership== The voting members of the NOCSAE board consists of representatives selected by their professional organizations, including:
* [[American Academy of Pediatrics]] * [[American College of Sports Medicine]] * [[American Medical Society for Sports Medicine]] * [[Athletic Equipment Managers Association]] * [[National Athletic Equipment Reconditioners Association]] * [[National Athletic Trainers' Association]] * [[Sporting and Fitness Industry Association]] * [[American Football Coaches Association]] * [[American Orthopedic Society for Sports Medicine]] and a non-voting representative from each the National Collegiate Athletic Association and the National Federation of State High School Associations.
==Criticisms== Critics note that NOCSAE has "a close working relationship with" the sporting goods industry,<ref name=Lipsey /> and that because NOCSAE is funded by those few companies, it has "an inherent conflict of interest".<ref name=Culverhouse /> They also claim that NOCSAE is not effective at lessening concussions and improving safety.<ref name=Culverhouse /> U.S. Senator [[Tom Udall]] of New Mexico requested that a federal agency, the [[Consumer Products Safety Commission]], assume an official role in helmet safety testing and certification, effectively displacing NOCSAE.<ref name=Culverhouse />
NOCSAE's certification standards have been criticized for authorizing helmet models that are "archaic or did not score well on specific impact tests."<ref name=Borden /> In addition, NOCSAE's tests focus on preventing [[Catastrophic injury|catastrophic injuries]] like skull fractures, not concussions.<ref name=Borden /> Observers note that such testing is equivalent to judging a car's safety based on its seat belts, with no consideration given to air bags.<ref name=Borden />
The sole reliance of the [[NFL]] on NOCSAE certification, without considering the tested safety results and other data on helmet models, has been criticized by the players' union.<ref name=Borden />
Critics note that while NOCSAE standards call for equipment to be reconditioned, where possible, and recertified every year,<ref name=Magee /> a school may keep its helmets as NOCSAE-certified simply by never submitting them for re-certification.<ref name=Nowinski />
The inflexible nature of NOCSAE guidelines, stemming from the hesitance of helmet manufacturers to take any risks that could lead to lawsuits,<ref name=Lipsey /> leads some to argue that innovative helmet designs may be underdeveloped.<ref name=Nowinski />

revision.text:
The '''New York State Athletic Commission''' or '''NYSAC''', also known as the '''New York Athletic Commission''', is a division of the [[New York State Department of State]] which regulates all contests and exhibitions of [[unarmed combat]] within the state of [[New York (state)|New York]], including licensure and supervision of promoters, [[boxing|boxers]], [[professional wrestling|professional wrestlers]], seconds, ring officials, managers, and matchmakers. In 2016, the NYSAC was authorized to oversee all [[mixed martial arts]] contests in New York.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://espn.go.com/mma/story/_/id/15046063/new-york-state-assembly-passes-bill-lifts-ban-mma|title=New York State Assembly passes bill that lifts ban on MMA|last1=Okamoto|first1=Brett|date=22 March 2016|website=espn.go.com|publisher=ESPN|access-date=11 July 2016}}</ref>
The commission is based in [[New York City]].
==NBA rivalry== The NYSAC was founded in 1920, when the [[Walker Law]] legalized prizefighting.<ref name="guin1"> {{cite book |last=Morrison |first=Ian |title=The Guinness World Championship Boxing book |publisher=Guinness Publishing |date=1990 |pages=14–15 |isbn=0-85112-900-5}} </ref> The National Boxing Association (NBA) was established in 1921 by other U.S. states to counter the influence of the NYSAC.<ref name="guin1"/> Sometimes the NYSAC and the NBA recognized different boxers as World Champion,<ref name="guin1"/> especially in 1927–40.<ref>Morrison, pp.126–137</ref> In 1962, the NBA renamed itself the [[World Boxing Association]], and in 1963 the NYSAC supported the formation of the [[World Boxing Council]].<ref name="guin1"/>
==Rules and Regulations (past and present) ==
===1929 Weights and classes=== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- !Class !Weight (lbs.) !Weight (kg) |- |Junior Flyweight||109||49.4 |- |Flyweight||112||50.8 |- |Junior Bantamweight||115||52.2 |- |Bantamweight||118||53.5 |- |Junior Featherweight||122||55.3 |- |Featherweight||126||57.2 |- |Junior Lightweight||130||59.0 |- |Lightweight||135||61.2 |- |Junior Welterweight||140||63.5 |- |Welterweight||147||66.7 |- |Middleweight||160||72.6 |- |Light Heavyweight||175||79.4 |}
===Boxing Rules of Athletic Commission of the State of New York=== <small>(As published in ''Self-Defense Sporting Annual'' 1929, p. 14.)</small>
===Referee=== *The referee shall order the power: **(a) To cast the third vote, in which case the three votes shall be of equal value. In the event of two votes coinciding, the result shall be so determined. In the event of all votes disagreeing, the contest shall be declared a draw. **(b) To stop a bout or contest at any stage and make a decision if he considers it too one-sided. **(c) To stop a bout or contest if he considers the competitors are not in earnest. In this case he may disqualify one or both contestants. **(d) To disqualify a contestant who commits a foul and to award decision to opponent. *The referee shall not touch the contesting boxers, except on failure of one or both contestants to obey the "break" command. *When a contestant is "down" the referee and timekeeper shall at once commence calling off the seconds and indicating the count with a motion of the arm. If the contestant fails to rise before count of ten, the referee shall declare him the loser. *Should a contestant who is "down" arise before count of ten is reached and again go down intentionally, without being struck, the referee and timekeeper shall resume count where it left off. *Should a contestant leave the ring during the one-minute rest period between rounds and fail to be in ring when gong rings to resume boxing, the referee shall count him out, the same as if he were "down." *If a contestant is down, his opponent shall retire to the farthest corner and remain there until the count is completed. Should he fail to do so, the referee and timekeeper may cease counting until he has so retired. *Referee shall decide all questions arising during a contest which are not specifically covered by these rules.
===Judges=== *The two judges shall be stationed at opposite sides of the ring. The decisions of the judges shall be based primarily on effectiveness, taking into account the following points: **1. A clean, forceful hit, landed on any vulnerable part of the body above the belt should be credited in proportion to its damaging effect. **2. Aggressiveness is next in importance and points should be awarded to the contestant who sustains the action of a round by the greatest number of skillful attacks. **3. Defensive work is relatively important and points should be given for cleverly avoiding or blocking a blow. **4. Points should be awarded where ring generalship is conspicuous. The comprises such points as the ability to quickly grasp and take advantage of every opportunity offered, the capacity to cope with all kinds of situations which may arise; to foresee and neutralize an opponent's method of attack; to force an opponent to adopt a style of boxing at which he is not particularly skillful. **5. It is advisable to deduct points when a contestant persistently delays the action of a contest by clinching and lack of aggressiveness. **6. Points should be deducted for a foul even though it is unintentional and not of a serious nature to warrant disqualification. **7. A contestant should be given credit for sportsmanlike actions in the ring, close adherence to the spirit as well as the letter of the rules and for refraining from taking technical advantage of situations unfair to an opponent. **8. In order to arrive at a true conclusion every point should be carefully observed and noted as the contest progresses, the decision going to the contestant who scores the greatest number of effective points regardless of the number of rounds won or lost. *When neither contestant has a decided margin in effectiveness, the winner should be determined on points scored and aggressiveness.
==Miscellaneous== *'''1922-06-01''': Adopts rule prohibiting boxers under the age of 20 from participating in bouts of more than six rounds. ''Wenatchee Daily World'' (Wenatchee, WA, USA) wire report. *'''1932-01-08''': Secretary Bert Stand announces that [[Battling Battalino]] forfeited his World Featherweight Title by stepping onto the scales overweight at 135¾ pounds, causing the first abandonment of a boxing match in the history of [[Madison Square Garden (1925)|Madison Square Garden]] on the afternoon of the night on which the match was scheduled, and the "only parallel for the situation in modern boxing" since the [[Charley (Phil) Rosenberg]] vs. [[Bushy Graham]] 1927 title bout. Lew Feldman, Battalino's scheduled opponent, immediately claims the title. ''New York Times''
==See also== {{portal|Martial Arts|New York}} *[[Association of Boxing Commissions]]
==References==
{{reflist}}
==External links== *{{official website|https://www.dos.ny.gov/athletic/about.html}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Use Pakistani English|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox sport governing body |name = Pakistan Blind Cricket Council |abbrev = PBCC |logo = |sport = [[Blind cricket]] |category = |image = |caption = |jurisdiction = National |founded = |aff = [[World Blind Cricket Council]] (WBCC)
[[Pakistan Cricket Board]] (PCB) |affdate = |region = South Asia |regionyear = |headquarters = [[Allama Iqbal Town]], [[Lahore]] |location = 660-Neelam Block |president = |chairman = Syed Sultan Shah |chairperson = |chair = |chiefexec = |secretary = |coach = |womenscoach = |key staff = |operating income = |sponsor = |year closed = |replaced = |prevfounded = |url = www.pbcc.org.pk |countryflag = Pakistan |countryflag2 = |countryflag3 = }} '''Pakistan Blind Cricket Council''' (PBCC) is a foundation for [[blind cricket]]ers in [[Pakistan]]. It controls and manages all the tours and matches undertaken by [[Pakistan blind cricket team]]. It was founded by ''Agha Shoukat Ali'' in 1996 for the development of cricket for blind and visually impaired individuals in Pakistan.{{cite news|title=Founder of PBCC "Agha Shaukat" passed away|url=http://www.nation.com.pk/pakistan-news-newspaper-daily-english-online/lahore/06-Apr-2009/Blind-crickets-Agha-Shaukat-passes-away|accessdate=December 13, 2012|newspaper=[[The Nation (Pakistani newspaper)|The Nation]]|date=April 6, 2009}} In August 1996, the first International Conference was held for blind cricket in [[Delhi]], [[India]], in which ''Pakistan Blind Cricket Council'' was registered by the ''[[World Blind Cricket Council]]'' (WBCC). == Presidents or Chairmen of PBCC == * ''Agha Shoukat Ali'' (Founder, President and Chairman) 1996 * ''Syed Sultan Shah'' (Chairman) Present == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{official website|http://www.pbcc.org.pk/}} * [http://static.espncricinfo.com/db/NATIONAL/PAK/ASSOCIATIONS/PBCC/ PBCC] at the [[ESPNcricinfo]] * {{facebook|116349845048137}} {{Blind cricket}} {{Sports governing bodies in Pakistan}}  [[Category:Cricket administration in Pakistan]] [[Category:Sports governing bodies in Pakistan]] [[Category:Cricket administration]] [[Category:Blind cricket administration]] [[Category:Pakistani disability sports organisations]] {{Pakistan-sport-stub}}

{{Infobox brand | name = Pony | logo = pony sports logo.png | logo_upright = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | image = | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | producttype = Athletic [[clothing]], [[footwear]] | currentowner = {{ubl|Pony International|(Symphony Holdings)}} | producedby = | origin = United States
Hong Kong (present) | introduced = 1972 | discontinued = | related = | markets = | previousowners = | trademarkregistrations = | ambassadors = | tagline = | website = {{url|www.pony-international.com|pony-international.com}} | module = | module1 = }} '''Pony''' is a brand of [[footwear]] and other [[clothing]]. It was founded in the [[United States]] and is now headquartered in [[Hong Kong]] under the company name '''Pony International'''.{{cite web |url=https://pony-international.com/contact-us/ |title=Our Headquarter [sic] |publisher=Pony International |accessdate=10 June 2018}} ==History== Founded in 1972 on Madison Avenue in [[New York City]], Pony was created by industry veteran (and Uruguayan-bornhttps://www.nylon.com/articles/pony-spring-14-collection) Roberto Muller, along with financing provided by adidas Chairman [[Horst Dassler]]. Pony became one of the top athletic brands worldwide. By the mid-1980s, Pony's sales volume reached US$800 million. The Pony brand has been worn by championship athletes in every major sport, including the [[FIFA World Cup]], the [[National Football League|NFL]]'s [[Super Bowl]], the [[Canadian Football League|CFL]]'s [[Grey Cup]], [[Major League Baseball|MLB]]'s [[World Series]], and the [[NBA Finals]]. Pony was owned by the English-based company Pentland in the 1990s before a sale to [[The Firm, Inc.|The Firm]] entertainment group, based in [[Santa Monica, California]]. The Firm relaunched the brand in 2001 with celebrity entertainers including [[Justin Timberlake]], [[Korn]], [[Snoop Dogg]] and [[Paris Hilton]]. In 2003, Global Brand Marketing, based in [[Santa Barbara, California]], acquired a majority share of Pony, along with Symphony Holdings and [[Itochu Corporation]]. In 2006, Pony was purchased by Symphony Holdings, a public company based in Hong Kong. Symphony brought in former partner Infinity Associates (Mardy Cason and Bill Simon), who were the principals who purchased [[Converse (shoe company)|Converse]] from bankruptcy in 2001, turned the brand around and sold to [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] in 2003 for $305 million. Jim Stroesser, who was the key partner in rebuilding Converse, was asked to be the CEO/President of Pony in 2006. Stroesser's team relocated Pony from Santa Barbara, CA, to downtown San Diego, CA. Pony was in need of a complete turnaround, and Stroesser's team rebuilt the company's infrastructure and positioned the brand as one of America's most authentic sports brands. In 2010 the company's U.S. headquarters were moved to [[Los Angeles]]. ==Offerings== Originally Pony was known for producing athletic footwear. The company expanded its offerings to include sports clothing, and has more recently produced [[streetwear]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|www.pony-international.com}} [[Category:Shoe brands]] [[Category:Sportswear brands]] [[Category:Clothing brands of the United States]] [[Category:Shoe companies of the United States]] [[Category:Clothing companies of the United States]] [[Category:Clothing companies established in 1972]] [[Category:1972 establishments in New York (state)]]

revision.text:
{{Distinguish|Slugging}} [[File:Babe Ruth2.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Babe Ruth]] holds the [[Major League Baseball|MLB]] career slugging percentage record (.690).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/slugging_perc_career.shtml|title=Career Leaders & Records for Slugging %|publisher=Baseball Reference|accessdate=2014-02-27}}</ref>]]
In [[baseball statistics]], '''slugging percentage''' ('''SLG''') is a measure of the batting productivity of a [[batting (baseball)|hitter]]. It is calculated as [[total bases]] divided by [[at bat]]s, through the following formula, where ''AB'' is the number of at bats for a given player, and ''1B'', ''2B'', ''3B'', and ''HR'' are the number of [[single (baseball)|singles]], [[double (baseball)|doubles]], [[triple (baseball)|triples]], and [[home run]]s, respectively:
: <math> \mathrm{SLG} = \frac{(\mathit{1B}) + (2 \times \mathit{2B}) + (3 \times \mathit{3B}) + (4 \times \mathit{HR})}{AB}</math>
Unlike [[batting average]], slugging percentage gives more weight to [[Extra-base hit|extra-base hits]] such as doubles and home runs, relative to singles. [[Base on balls|Walks]] are specifically excluded from this calculation, as a [[plate appearance]] that ends in a walk is not counted as an at bat.
The name is a [[misnomer]], as the statistic is not a [[percentage]] but a scale of [[Measure (mathematics)|measure]] whose computed value is a number from 0 to 4. The statistic gives a double twice the value of a single, a triple three times the value, and a homerun four times.<ref name="Baseball Scorekeeping: A Practical Guide, 2003">[https://books.google.com/books?id=AikEnbLTOF0C&pg=PA243&dq=%22slugging+percentage%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjem9Hym-zZAhVHZawKHT3uAdwQ6AEIXTAJ#v=onepage&q=%22slugging%20percentage%22&f=false Baseball Scorekeeping: A Practical Guide to the Rules], Andres Wirkmaa, Jefferson, North Carolina, London: McFarland & Company, Inc., Publishers, 2003.</ref>
A slugging percentage is always expressed as a [[decimal]] to three decimal places, and is generally spoken as if multiplied by 1000. For example, a slugging percentage of .589 would be spoken as "five eighty nine."
In [[2016 Major League Baseball season|2016]], the mean average SLG among all batters in [[Major League Baseball]] was .417.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/leaders.aspx?pos=all&stats=bat&lg=all&qual=0&type=8&season=2016&month=0&season1=2016&ind=0&team=0,ss&rost=0&age=0&filter=&players=0|title=Major League Total Stats » 2016 » Batters » Dashboard {{!}} FanGraphs Baseball|website=www.fangraphs.com|access-date=2017-04-30}}</ref>
== Example calculation == For example, in 1920, [[Babe Ruth]] played his first season for the [[New York Yankees]]. In 458 at bats, Ruth had 172 hits, comprising 73 singles, 36 doubles, 9 triples, and 54 home runs, which brings the total base count to {{nowrap|1=(73 × 1) + (36 × 2) + (9 × 3) + (54 × 4) = 388}}. His total number of bases (388) divided by his total at-bats (458) is .847 which constitutes his slugging percentage for the season. This also set a record for Ruth which stood until [[2001 in baseball|2001]] when [[Barry Bonds]] achieved 411 bases in 476 at-bats bringing his slugging percentage to .863, which has been unmatched since.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/leaders/slugging_perc_season.shtml|title=Single-Season Leaders & Records for Slugging %|publisher=Baseball Reference|accessdate=2016-12-10}}</ref>
==Significance== Long after it was first invented, slugging percentage gained new significance when baseball analysts realized that it combined with [[on-base percentage]] (OBP) to form a very good measure of a player's overall offensive production (in fact, OBP + SLG was originally referred to as "production" by baseball writer and statistician [[Bill James]]). A predecessor metric was developed by [[Branch Rickey]] in 1954. Rickey, in ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'' magazine, suggested that combining OBP with what he called "extra base power" (EBP) would give a better indicator of player performance than typical [[Major League Baseball Triple Crown|Triple Crown]] stats. EBP was a predecessor to slugging percentage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://old.nationalreview.com/weekend/play-ball/pb-lewis033101.shtml|title=Lies, Damn Lies, and RBIs|accessdate=2012-07-01|date=2001-03-31|first=Dan|last=Lewis|publisher=nationalreview.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121020211628/http://old.nationalreview.com/weekend/play-ball/pb-lewis033101.shtml|archivedate=2012-10-20|df=}}</ref>
[[Allen Barra]] and [[George Ignatin]] were early adopters in combining the two modern-day statistics, multiplying them together to form what is now known as "SLOB" (Slugging × On-Base).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/news/sports/col/barra/2001/06/20/bonds/print.html|title=The best season ever?|accessdate= 2007-07-15|date= 2001-06-20|first=Allen|last= Barra|publisher=Salon.com}}</ref> [[Bill James]] applied this principle to his [[runs created]] formula several years later (and perhaps independently), essentially multiplying SLOB × At-Bats to create the formula:
: <math>\text{RC}=\frac{(\text{hits}+\text{walks})\times(\text{total bases})}{(\text{at-bats}) + (\text{walks})}</math>
In 1984, [[Pete Palmer]] and [[John Thorn]] developed perhaps the most widespread means of combining slugging and on-base percentage: [[On-base plus slugging]] (OPS), which is a simple addition of the two values. Because it is easy to calculate, OPS has been used with increased frequency in recent years as a shorthand form to evaluate contributions as a [[Batting (baseball)|batter]].
In a 2015 article, Bryan Grosnick made the point that "on base" and "slugging" may not be comparable enough to be simply added together. "On base" has a theoretical maximum of 1.000 whereas "slugging" has a theoretical maximum of 4.000. The actual numbers don't show as big a difference of course, with Grosnick listing .350 as a good "on base" and .430 as a good "slugging." He goes on to say that OPS has the advantages of simplicity and availability and further states, "you'll probably get it 75% right, at least."<ref>[https://www.beyondtheboxscore.com/2015/9/18/9329763/separate-but-not-quite-equal-why-ops-is-a-bad-statistic Separate but not quite equal: Why OPS is a "bad" statistic], Bryan Grosnick, Beyond the Box Score, Sept. 18, 2015.</ref>
==Perfect slugging percentage== The maximum numerically possible slugging percentage is 4.000.<ref name="Baseball Scorekeeping: A Practical Guide, 2003"/> A number of MLB players (117 through the end of the 2016 season) have momentarily had a 4.000 career slugging percentage by [[List of Major League Baseball players with a home run in their first major league at bat|homering in their first major league at-bat]]. Hundreds of other players have momentarily held a 4.000 percentage for a season by hitting a home run in their first at-bat of the season.
No player has ever retired with a 4.000 slugging percentage, but four players tripled in their only MLB at-bat and therefore share the record of a career slugging percentage of 3.000 (when evaluated without regard to a minimum number of games played or plate appearances). The players are [[Eric Cammack]] (2000 Mets), [[Scott Munninghoff]] (1980 Phillies), [[Eduardo Rodríguez (right-handed pitcher)|Eduardo Rodríguez]] (1973 Brewers), and [[Charlie Lindstrom]] (1958 White Sox).<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/baseball/2010/05/29/2010-05-29_baseballs_triple_threats.html |location=New York |work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]] |title=Ex-Met Eric Cammack is one of only four players to post career slugging percentage of 3.000 |first=Jesse |last=Spector |date=2010-05-29}}</ref>

{{Other uses}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox sport | image = Snooker table selby.JPG | imagesize = 300px | caption = 2014, 2016 and 2017 world champion [[Mark Selby]] playing a practice game | union = [[World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association|WPBSA]]
[[International Billiards and Snooker Federation|IBSF]] | first = 1870s | contact = Non-contact | category = [[Cue sports|Cue sport]] | equipment = Snooker table, [[Billiard ball#Snooker|snooker balls]], [[cue stick|cue]], triangle, chalk | venue = Snooker Table | olympic = [[International Olympic Committee|IOC]] recognition[https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/snooker/30942350 "Snooker bids to be included in 2020 Olympics in Tokyo"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151016034358/http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/snooker/30942350 |date=16 October 2015 }}, BBC Sport, 22 January 2015, (Retrieved 28 April 2015) | IWGA = [[2001 World Games|2001]]{{snds}}present }} '''Snooker''' ({{IPAc-en|UK|ˈ|s|n|uː|k|ər}}, {{IPAc-en|US|ˈ|s|n|ʊ|k|ər}}){{cite web |title=Pronunciation of ''snooker'' |work=Macmillan Dictionary |url=http://www.macmillandictionary.com/pronunciation/british/snooker |publisher=Macmillan Publishers |location=London, UK |accessdate=19 March 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120415162427/http://www.macmillandictionary.com/pronunciation/british/snooker |archivedate=15 April 2012 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |title=American pronunciation of ''snooker'' |work=Macmillan Dictionary |url=http://www.macmillandictionary.com/pronunciation/american/snooker |publisher=op. cit. |accessdate=19 March 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130512225433/http://www.macmillandictionary.com/pronunciation/american/snooker |archivedate=12 May 2013 |df=dmy-all }} is a [[Cue sports|cue sport]] which originated among [[British Army]] officers stationed in India in the later half of the 19th century. It is played on a rectangular [[Billiard table#Snooker tables|table]] covered with a green cloth, or [[baize]], with [[Billiard table#Pockets 2|pockets]] at each of the four corners and in the middle of each long side. Using a [[cue stick|cue]] and 22 [[Billiard ball#Snooker|coloured ball]]s, players must strike the white ball (or "cue ball") to {{glossary link|glossary=Glossary of cue sports terms|pot}} the remaining balls in the correct sequence, accumulating points for each pot. An individual game, or frame, is won by the player who scores the most points. A match is won when a player wins a predetermined number of frames. Snooker gained its own identity in 1884 when army officer [[Neville Francis Fitzgerald Chamberlain|Sir Neville Chamberlain]] (not the [[Neville Chamberlain|Prime Minister]] of that name), while stationed in [[Ooty]], devised a set of rules that combined [[pyramid pool|pyramid]] and [[life pool]]. {{cite web |url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neville_Chamberlain_(disambiguation) |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2018-05-03 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070601033451/https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neville_Chamberlain_(disambiguation) |archivedate=1 June 2007 |df=dmy-all }}, retrieved 25 February 2007 The word "snooker" was a long-used military term used to describe inexperienced or first-year personnel. The game grew in popularity in England, and the Billiards Association and Control Club was formed in 1919. It is now governed by the [[World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association]] (WPBSA). The [[World Snooker Championship]] has taken place since [[1927 World Snooker Championship|1927]], with [[Joe Davis]] becoming a key figure in the early growth of the sport with 15 championship wins from 1927 to 1946. The modern era began in 1969 after the [[BBC]] commissioned the snooker television show ''[[Pot Black]]'' and began to air the World Championship in [[1978 World Snooker Championship|1978]], leading to the sport's new peak in popularity. [[Ray Reardon]] dominated the game in the 1970s, [[Steve Davis]] in the 1980s, and [[Stephen Hendry]] in the 1990s; [[Ronnie O'Sullivan]] has won the most world titles since 2000. Top professional players now compete regularly around the world and earn millions of pounds.Reardon, R. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/snooker/4283589.stm "Where does Ronnie rank?"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070601033451/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/snooker/4283589.stm |date=1 June 2007 }}, BBC Sport, 21 February 2005, (Retrieved 25 February 2007) The sport has become increasingly popular in China.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/6288739.stm "China in Ding's hands"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070226040032/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/6288739.stm |date=26 February 2007 }}, BBC Sport, 22 January 2007, (Retrieved 25 February 2007) ==History== {{Main article|History of snooker}} [[File:Neville Francis Fitzgerald Chamberlain.png|thumb|right|upright|[[Neville Francis Fitzgerald Chamberlain|Sir Neville Chamberlain]], a British Army officer who devised the game and its rules in the late 19th century.]] The origin of snooker dates back to the latter half of the 19th century.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/sporting-vernacular-11-snooker-1089731.html|first=Chris|last=Maume|title=Sporting Vernacular 11. Snooker|work=The Independent|date=25 April 1999|accessdate=25 February 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211083228/http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/sporting-vernacular-11-snooker-1089731.html|archivedate=11 February 2017|df=dmy-all}} In the 1870s, [[English billiards|billiards]] was a popular activity amongst [[British Army]] officers stationed in [[India]] and several variations of the game were devised during this time. One such variation originated at the officers' [[mess]] of the 11th [[Devonshire Regiment]] in 1875,{{cite web|url=http://www.snookerheritage.co.uk/normans-articles/days-of-old/origins-of-snooker/|title=Origins of Snooker|first=Peter|last=Clare|date=2008|publisher=Snooker Heritage|accessdate=8 February 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170103150005/http://snookerheritage.co.uk/normans-articles/days-of-old/origins-of-snooker/|archivedate=3 January 2017|df=dmy-all}} which combined the rules of two [[pocket billiards]] games, [[pyramid pool|pyramid]] and [[life pool]]. The former was played with fifteen red balls and one black positioned in a triangle, while the latter involved the potting of designated coloured balls.Shamos, Mike (1993), ''The Complete Book of Billiards''. {{ISBN|0-517-20869-5}} The game developed its own identity in 1884 when its first set of rules was finalised by [[Neville Francis Fitzgerald Chamberlain|Sir Neville Chamberlain]], an English officer who helped develop and popularise the game at [[Stone House, Ooty|Stone House]] in [[Ooty]] on a table built by Burroughes & Watts that was brought over by boat.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/destinations/asia/india/articles/Ooty-India-back-in-time-to-the-birthplace-of-snooker/|title=Ooty, India: back in time to the birthplace of snooker|date=16 June 2014|work=The Telegraph|first=Martin|last=Hughes-Games|accessdate=8 February 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170321074803/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/destinations/asia/india/articles/Ooty-India-back-in-time-to-the-birthplace-of-snooker/|archivedate=21 March 2017|df=dmy-all}} The word "snooker" was a slang term for first-year cadets and inexperienced military personnel, but Chamberlain would often use it to describe the inept performance of one of his fellow officers at the table. The name instantly stuck with the players.{{cite web |author= |title=Origins of the Game of Snooker |url= http://www.titansports.co.uk/history/snooker.htm |work=TitanSports.co.uk |date= |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20051215154838/http://www.titansports.co.uk/history/snooker.htm |archive-date=15 December 2005 |dead-url=yes |access-date=13 November 2017}}{{unreliable source|certain=y|date=November 2017|reason=Just some unknown-author rambling on vendor website. There are real sources for this out there.}} In 1887, snooker was given its first definite reference in England in a copy of ''[[Sporting Life (British newspaper)|Sporting Life]]'' which caused a growth in popularity. Chamberlain came out as the game's inventor in a letter to ''[[The Field (magazine)|The Field]]'' published on 19 March 1938, 63 years after the fact. Snooker grew in popularity across the Indian colonies and the United Kingdom, but it remained a game mainly for the [[gentry]], and many gentlemen's clubs that had a billiards table would not allow non-members inside to play. To accommodate the growing interest, smaller and more open snooker-specific clubs were formed. In 1919, the Billiards Association and the Billiards Control Board merged to form the Billiards Association and Control Club (BA&CC) and a new, standard set of rules for snooker first became official.{{sfn|Gadsby|Williams|2012|p=8}} The game of snooker grew in the latter half of the 19th century and the early 20th century, and by [[1927 World Snooker Championship|1927]] the first [[World Snooker Championship]] had been organised by [[Joe Davis]] who, as a professional [[English billiards]] and snooker player, moved the game from a [[Hobby|pastime]] activity into a more professional sphere.unknown author [http://www.cuesnviews.co.uk/Snooker/timeline.htm "Snooker Timeline"] ''"Joe Davis will reinvent this after-dinner pastime and become world champion"'', cuesnviews.co.uk, unknown date, (Retrieved 24 February 2007), ([https://web.archive.org/web/20060216115629/http://www.cuesnviews.co.uk/Snooker/timeline.htm Archive Version]) Davis won every world championship until 1946 when he retired. The game went into a decline through the 1950s and 1960s with little interest generated outside of those who played. In 1959, Davis introduced a variation of the game known as "snooker plus" (see the ''Variations'' section below) to try to improve the game's popularity by adding two extra colours, but it never caught on. A major advance occurred in 1969, when [[David Attenborough]] commissioned the snooker television series ''[[Pot Black]]'' to demonstrate the potential of [[Color television#Europe|colour television]] with the green table and multi-coloured balls being ideal for showing off the advantages of colour broadcasting.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/snooker/4382776.stm "Pot Black returns"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061117104945/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/snooker/4382776.stm |date=17 November 2006 }}, BBC Sport, 27 October 2005.
